summary: This is an email chain from June 2008 between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel regarding the Jeffrey Epstein plea agreement. It discusses finalizing the agreement, mentions a '2255 issue' (likely a habeas corpus motion), and references search warrants and coordinating the change of plea and sentencing.

persons.name: Roy Black
persons.context: Addressed in an email regarding the Jeffrey Epstein agreement, indicating he is part of the defense legal team.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: Addressed alongside Roy Black in an email regarding the Jeffrey Epstein agreement, indicating he is part of the defense legal team.

connections.description: Both are addressed as defense attorneys for Jeffrey Epstein in the same email regarding the plea agreement.

events.title: Email on Epstein Agreement
events.description: An email is sent from a U.S. Attorney to defense attorneys Roy Black and Jack Goldberger stating the government's position that a signed, binding plea agreement exists and requesting information on the date and time for the change of plea and sentencing.

events.title: Discussion of Plea Agreement Solution
events.description: An email indicates a solution has been designed for a '2255 issue' (likely related to 28 U.S.C. ยง 2255 habeas corpus motions) and that a call will be made to discuss the plea. The sender is finishing search warrants.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office asserts in June 2008 that a signed, binding plea agreement with Jeffrey Epstein exists and requires no further modification.
A '2255 issue' (a reference to post-conviction habeas corpus relief) is mentioned as being addressed with a designed solution.
The correspondence references ongoing work on search warrants and coordination for Epstein's change of plea and sentencing.
The email chain involves communication between U.S. Attorney personnel and Epstein's defense attorneys, Roy Black and Jack Goldberger.
